Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2008 12:03AM wallycat wrote: Here's my angle on this.... I personally agree that staging a tumor simply classifies it because docs have guidelines on treatment.  BUT....certain tumors are more aggressive (the grade matters).   My extrapolation of that data is that if a gal foregoes getting checked and has a slow growing tumor, it could be there for 10 years when finally detected.  If she'd found it at year 3, it would be a stage 1 but maybe at year 10, it has grown in size, which forces the hand to classify it at a stage 3.  Similarly, if you have a fast growing tumor, and you wait 10 years....well it could be stage iv  and if you catch it in year 1 or 2, it is a stage 3 because it was a faster grower (mitosis rate) than the first example. To me, grade is more important than stage, and pathology is more important (er/pr status, her2-neu, nodes, etc...)  ......to me the size of the tumor implies how long it took to find.  To that end, it only makes a difference because more aggressive tumors get bigger in less time.

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2008 07:15PM wallycat wrote: I am sorry you are feeling unhappy. Here's my story.  From the beginning, I knew i'd want a bilateral (proph. for left side, necessary for right).  I am a worrier and I didn't want to do rads. My surgeon (whom I adore and respect very much) insisted on lumpectomy.  He said mastectomy was overkill. I decided to let them do the lumpectomy so I would get a path report and see what I was dealing with. Once the report came back, I politely said to my surgeon "I hope you won't be mad that I am killing your good work...I still want the bilaterals."  He was happy to do it once I met with a plastic surgeon and a radiation oncologist ...so that I was SURE and knew going in that I'd made the right decision. You may want to do the same.  Some gals report a slightly larger breast after rads, others even smaller.  Also, I opted no recon; rads will alter if/when you can get reconstruction done. Yes, it is annoying to go under twice, and the cording and arm raising stretches all over again, but it was the difference of a few months and for me, knowing pathology before I proceeded with bilaterals made me feel more secure. Best to you!

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2012 12:56PM wallycat wrote: Can a lump "turn into cancer?"  Here is my take, such as it is...since ANY cell in the body can become cancer, lumps, skin, etc....anything CAN become cancer.  Does a b-9 lump typically turn into cancer?  Not typically, but we are all playing the odds. My eye doctor's wife had a breast biopsy for a suspicious area...the person performing the biopsy missed the lesion they were looking at in the ultrasound...got surrounding tissue. Saved her life since THAT tissue turned out to be cancer. Can you live 25 years with cancer and not have issues...yes.  If there is a slow growing cancer, why not?  Some studies show that auto-accident victims who have been autopsied show some women with BC and they are in their 70s, 80s, etc....did they know?  How long was it there? They are telling men with prostate cancer to watch and wait---something else will get them, so why not other cancers. Dermoid tumors on ovaries are typically b-9, but in a small % (and in older women) they have found cancer cells... Cancer is a crap shoot and the more I read, the more I say finding it is equally crappy!

By doing mx, I could avoid rads.  I also would not need 6 month follow ups for life.  I was also beating cancer before it picked up healthy left breast and decided how far it could spread. For me, and me alone, the decision was crystal clear in my head.  I was too chicken to do the implants, and I confess, being flat chested after schlepping 36Ds for most of my life is VERY freeing.  It is amazing how quickly the human body/mind come together to accept the reality of the "new you."  I still cry and have horribly deep moments of bitterness and anger (which people tell me I ought to go get some counseling for) that I got the cancer to begin with, but the decision I made...I've never looked back. Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2008 10:06PM wallycat wrote: I am so sorry you are dealing with this stuff....the anxiety alone can give us symptoms that are unbelievable. You didn't say how old you are or your family history, but here is my 2 cents worth.... The odds are it is nothing.  Even breast lumps, they say 80% of them are b-9.  Coming to a breast cancer BB, of course you are reading everyone who DID have cancer, but not all of those that did not.  MOST breast cancers start in the breast.....so I would ask for a mammogram and a possible MRI.  They say the MRI is the "gold standard" for ruling it in or out.  I would also ask for an aspiration if you still have the lump (it is likely to be a sweat gland or a fatty deposit, but around here, we say the only good lump is one in a jar).   Remember that most cancers are years in the making, which means a day or a week is not going to affect your outcome overall. I too was going to suggest your thyroid be checked.  Hyperthyroid can make you drop weight almost overnight.    We hope to hear you post back that you are fine.  Please follow up for peace of mind, but try not to assume it is more than it is. I was one of those gals that had a gut feel; clean mammo, clean ultrasound but got an MRI...and still no pallpable mass.  I am still a stage 1.  Don't overstress as the examinations begin. Best to you.

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2016 11:37AM wallycat wrote: I had BMX and sentinel node biopsy (5 nodes). I am starting year 9. I have had zero issues with pain (even the day after surgery, I needed zero pain meds--doc was very puzzled). It took about a week for range of motion with the lumpectomy (initial surgery) and no issues with range of motion after BMX. I think 3 months after, I may have popped one ibuprofen, but otherwise, have not required any pain meds, have no range of motion issues (I can still do my back bends and various yoga poses that I have always done). As the nerves re-grow, I am getting sensation in my chest (not the sexy-good kind), but still no pain, knock wood. Still gets to me some days about the concave look, but I do not regret my decision for BMX. I know there are some gals who have had pain from the get-go and it breaks my heart. Being told you have cancer is bad enough....but at least I don't have that issue.

Posts.Content: May 23, 2008 07:44PM wallycat wrote: Yes it does.  I hated when I was told to be patient, but it is true. You can't compare your healing/recovery to anyone because we are all so different. I think it depends on how much exercise you did prior (just my own belief). I had lumpectomy with SNB and it seemed to take forever for range of motion...for me a month.  About as soon as I healed, I asked for bilaterals, so had to start the range of motion stuff all over again.  SNB really was the harder healing. If you find yourself stiff and in pain, go for physical therapy. I ended up having a pinched nerve in my left (non-cancer) side that was sooooooo painful, it was worse than the mastectomy (and I had no pain pills).  I wanted to die and sobbed for 3 days and finally caved in to go to the PT.  Within an hour, the pain was gone!  Plus, she did massages for 6 weeks to get the cording worked out.  By the time she was done, I had full range of motion....that and yoga really helped me. Best to you.  Be good to yourself and give yourself time.

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2013 04:42PM wallycat wrote: Since I opted out of rads for bx mx, I can only talk about the surgery.  Zero pain.  My surgeon freaked when he saw the pain drip in the hallway and not hooked up to me.  I think within the first month, I took 1 tylenol.  It was just a weird feeling and not even pain, but the 1 pill was enough for the remainder of my recovery.  Radiation will have its own set of side effects and there is no predicting if/what/when they will occur, which is why I wanted to opt out.  I won't write horror stories here since we have already established that we all respond differently. Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2008 04:43PM wallycat wrote: It is painless and very easy. You are injected with a dye and then they lay you face down on the machine (some are open, some enclosed).  The bed of the machine has 2 holes where your breasts drop down, and the machine scans them using the dye.  Some people complain the machine is loud but I slept through the whole thing.  Once the machine determines where the area of suspect is, a radiologist will do a needle guided biopsy.  They numb the area so you cannot feel anything.  For me, they had to cut all the way through the whole breast because of how the tumor was positioned and the machine and I still felt nothing.  They will leave a tiny titanium clip for future reference (either for the lumpectomy if needed or for future MRIs --which I hope is your case.).  NOT all lit up areas that are biopsied are cancer.  Mine was; my twin sister's was not. Good luck. p.s. don't forget you can ask for a valium or atavan (sp?) or something for the anxiety.

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2019 05:05PM wallycat wrote: I'm so sorry you are forced to even think about this at your age! From how I am understanding your posts, you have zero idea if this is invasive or not. If it is DCIS, then there is no rush to do anything. Some studies are saying imaging has gotten so good that many women would walk around for years before DCIS was even diagnosed. Still, they do not know which DCIS will become invasive or stay dormant and just "be" there without causing issue. You don't need to make any decisions till you know what you are dealing with. For myself, I chose BMX because I was large breasted and did not want to feel lopsided and always having to wear a prosthetic going out. I did not want recon, so that would have been my only choice. If you choose recon, the odds are that you will require new implants in 10-20 or so years and since you are so young, another surgery would no doubt be in your future. There are recon options that use your own fat, but with 2 small children, you'd have to factor that in. I'm mentioning this because you indicated BMX decision so you won't go through another surgery...so maybe saving a healthy breast and not "killing it" (to use your words) is an option. There's no guarantee that you would go on to develop a second breast cancer. Keep us posted on your decision and keep an open mind. The more details and information you have, the easier (sometimes) it is to make the decision. Good luck and so sorry you are here.

I think if I were in my 30's or early 40's, I may have considered reconstruction.  Frankly, I didn't realize I could opt out of reconstruction till my husband said something!  We went to the plastic surgeon together and after our initial discussions and pamphlets,  I was to decide.  As we reached the elevator my DH had a very puzzled look on his face.  "Am I getting this correctly?" he asked.  "They cut a perfectly good pectoralis muscle to put these implants in?"   He just couldn't wrap his brain on this ....to which I explained that yes, that was how silicone implants are done.  "And why would any woman do that to herself?" he asked....this should let you know that my DH is not a boob man (thankfully).  Until his comments, I never even thought that NOT reconstructing is a perfectly good option.   Once I began reading some of the problems that may happen, the pain that may occur and that it would involve another replacement surgery, I knew in my heart that no matter how much I missed my boobs and wished they would be back, I was unwilling to go through all of that to have the look. Many gals are very happy with their decision to have reconstruction, but I guess I'm a very happy girl to be flat. Best to you with your decision.

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2008 06:24PM - edited Jun 15, 2008 06:27PM by wallycat I am so sorry you are going through this.   Cancer is out of our control. I would urge you to speak to a genetic counselor and maybe a support group. Genetic testing is risky because though carrying a certain gene may predispose you (put you at higher risk) of a disease, it doesn't mean you will get it.  Still, BRCA plus your mother's history certainly puts you at that nasty "higher risk" status. Has your doctor talked about Oopherectomy? or did you decide you wanted this on your own?  No one can make decisions about surgeries but you. We can suggest what "we" (individually) would do in a similar situation but that doesn't mean it would be right for you. If you were prepared to go ahead with the surgeries, can you reschedule to move things up?  I ended up testing negative for the BRCA1/2 but was prepared to have ovaries and breasts removed.  I ended up just having bilateral mastectomy because of ILC in right breast. It was 1 year on Friday and I have not regretted my decision. I'm a worrier and for me, the peace of mind in risk reduction (though not nil, much less risk) was worth it.  Not everyone is a worrier and not everyone opts for this route. Best to you on this icky journey we women deal with. I will add that I ended up having to wait nearly 2 months to get my MRI and then go back for a second MRI for the biopsy....It is June and if your surgeries are July/August, I would think you could wait.  My only concern is about a second surgery to do SNB because they don't know if it is cancer or not.  Maybe they can do a preliminary rush of the mass and then do the PBM, and then decide on the nodes. Again, best to you!
